Title: MRI: Acquisition of Atomic Layer Deposition Device for Nanoscale Materials Development Research

Significance
The new capabilities of the instrument will create an immediate and lasting impact on their ability to recruit high-quality faculty members. As Villanova hires its next generation of faculty members, it will be offer access to leading-edge equipment. The emphasis on nanomaterials fabrication and development necessitates the upgrading of their experimental facilities to attract leading researchers and educators who can make an immediate impact as they join this dynamic group. The PI and co-PIs are all dedicated to improving opportunities and access for under-represented minorities in engineering and the sciences and two of the principals on this grant are female STEM faculty members. The five PIs combined are advising 16 graduate students, 7 of whom are women, and are working with 19 undergraduate students, including 5 women. Bryn Mawr College was established in 1885 as the first institution in the US to offer Ph.D. degrees to women and the undergraduate program remains all-female, featuring 1300 women, 26% of whom are majoring in math or science. The Villanova College of Engineering also features one of the highest percentages of female students studying engineering, at almost 1/3 of the engineering school enrollment.

Technical Description
The Villanova Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) facility will serve as a center for collaborative nanomaterials research and development linking five faculty at three Philadelphia-region colleges and universities. The collaborating faculty have been using an existing first generation ALD device at the University of Pennsylvania, but the expansion and growth in externally funded thin film nanomaterials development research activity by the three Villanova faculty has led to difficulties in coordination and timing with the Penn facilities. The Villanova facility will greatly enhance faculty and student access and allow the overall team to greatly expand their collaborative work. The Villanova facility will feature an ALD system with significantly upgraded capabilities. The system will be faster and feature improved batch operation, allowing the scheduling of a greater volume of work, and feature the ability to do both thermal and plasma deposition. The addition of plasma deposition technology features greater precision and control of the deposition process leading to significantly higher film quality. The plasma deposition process features enhanced nucleation and growth of the films, leading to greater homogeneity and film density. The plasma process also enables the deposition of a much wider variety of thin film materials enabling critical new research areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded the purchase and installation of a plasma-enhanced atomic layer deposition (PEALD) instrument for a southeast Pennsylvania consortium of colleges which includes Villanova University, Bryn Mawr College and the University of Pennsylvania.  The instrument is located at Villanova and the facility now serves as a center for collaborative nanomaterials research and development linking these colleges and universities. The establishment of the Villanova facility has greatly enhanced faculty and student access and allow the overall team to expand their collaborative work.

The Villanova facility features a VEECO/Ultratech Cambridge NanoTech (CNT) Fiji G2 plasma-enhanced atomic layer deposition (PEALD) system. Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) is a thin film deposition technique which allows the deposition of thin films over nanomaterials for reinforcement leading to the creation of high quality nanostructured materials. ALD allows ultrahigh precision control over the film deposition process, providing superior film conformity and uniformity even for complex structures.  The ALD technique has been used to successfully deposit thin films using many different elements including metals, oxides, nitrides, III-V semiconductors, and organic materials.   PEALD is a state of the art plasma-enhanced ALD process.  The plasma enhancement allows the creation of a wider variety of thin films, and at lower temperatures, allowing film deposition on flexible substrates like polymers, greatly extending the number of potential applications and enabling critical new research areas. The addition of plasma deposition technology also enables greater precision and control of the deposition process leading to significantly higher film quality. The plasma deposition process features enhanced nucleation and growth of the films, leading to greater homogeneity and film density. The PEALD system is integrated with an in-situ JA Woollam M2000D Ellipsometer which is used to characterize the thickness and optical properties of the ALD coating during ALD process. The in-situ PEALD system was purchased in 2016 and installed and fully functional in 2017.

Multiple regional training sessions have been held on the instrument for more than a dozen graduate and undergraduate students from all three institutions and the students are now using the instrument in their research work. Some examples of collaborative ongoing work include: Lin Zhang, co-advised by Fleischer (PI) and Feng (co-PI), is using the PEALD to Xiaosong Liu, co-advised by Fleischer (PI) and Feng (co-PI), is developing new heat spreading materials using micro encapsulated phase change materials bound together using ALD. Lu An, advised by Feng (co-PI), is using the PEALD to enhance nanoparticle assemblies for optical studies and applications. Guanglei Chen, advised by C. Li (co-PI), is using the PEALD to enhance nanostructured metallic surfaces for two-phase change heat transfer enhancement.  Jyo Lyn Hor and Neha Manohar, advised by Lee (co-PI) at UPenn, are working on depositing alucone polymer coatings for enhancing and functionalizing nanomaterials.

Finally, the principles behind the instrument itself are now being taught in various classes, expanding the impact of the equipment to a larger audience. G. Feng (co-PI) has developed a module on Nanomaterials Synthesis, in the graduate-level ME 7250 Nano and Microscale Materials Behavior class. This module in ME 7250 is on the theory and applications of several advanced thin film deposition method, particularly atomic layer deposition (ALD) technique.   At the undergraduate level, B. Li has developed a module on nanomanufacturing, in the junior-level-required ME 3333 Manufacturing Engineering class. This module introduces various nanomanufacturing techniques, including ALD.
